results.title: Beauty and the beast (Disney)
results.creator_credit: Don Hahn, Walt Disney Pictures, Silver Screen Partners IV, Gary Trousdale and Kirk Wise
results.brief_description: This animated “tale as old as time” follows the adventures of Belle, a bright young woman imprisoned in the castle of a mysterious beast. With the assistance of the castle’s enchanted staff, a tender romance develops between these two unlikely friends and Belle learns the most important lesson of all, that true beauty comes from within. Voices include Angela Lansbsury, Robby Benson and David Ogden Stiers. (Awards: Oscar winning music: Best Song and Best Score).
results.creator_credit_for_label: Don Hahn, Walt Disney Pictures, Silver Screen Partners IV, Gary Trousdale and Kirk Wise

results.title: Beautiful Lennard Island
results.creator_credit: ONF | NFB, Yuki Yoshida, Kathleen Shannon and Beverly Shaffer
results.brief_description: Steven Thomas Holland, age ten, is the son of a lighthouse-keeper who mans Lennard Island, a tiny place west of Vancouver Island. There is a population of four: mother, father and brother David. A gracious host and articulate fan of his beautiful island home, he takes us on a tour and dispels any ideas we might have that living in isolation is boring.

results.title: Beau Geste
results.creator_credit: Barry Letts, British Broadcasting Corporation and Douglas Camfield
results.brief_description: From the novel by P.C. Wren, “Beau Geste” is the adventures of three aristocratic British brothers who turn their backs on their privileged lives and join the French Foreign Legion. Drawn together by the ties of blood and loyalty, their courage and honour are tested in the harsh desert world. This is another excellent BBC adaptation and stars Benedict Taylor as Beau Geste, Anthony Calf as Digby and Johnathon Morris as John.

results.title: Beating the drum
results.creator_credit: Fiona Cochrane, Louise Hubbard, F-Reel Pty Ltd and Film Finance Corporation Australia
results.brief_description: Melbourne has proven to be a mecca of sorts for musicians, with virtually any style of music being performed in clubs and halls across the city at any one time. ‘Beating the drum’ showcases some of these extraordinary performers who have migrated to Australia- some retain their traditional style, others have blended it in collaboration with other musicians. Both methods reflect the bigger issue of the cultural appropriation of music- whether there is such a thing, is there a right and wrong way to do it, how does Aboriginal music fit into this notion, and what we mean by world music? Musicians, academics, broadcasters and World Music aficionados take up this discussion through words and music. Musicians include: Xylouris Ensemble, Kavisha Mazzella and La Voce Della Luna, George Telek, Rembetika Compania, Terrasphere, Tom E. Lewis, Inka Marka, Taksim, Thula Sana, Adzohu, Fronteras, Vladimir Kocibelli, Petrunka, Tsicaderis Ensemble and Ta’Esh Fa’Esh.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Fiona Cochrane, Louise Hubbard, F-Reel Pty Ltd and Film Finance Corporation Australia

results.title: Beating the clock - at work: the limits of human performance
results.creator_credit: Steve Skok, Victoria. Dept. of Education and Early Childhood Development and Jeff Spencer
results.brief_description: Looks at ways in which people try to enhance their performance levels in relation to real or perceived times and the ensuing results.

results.title: Beating the clock - at sport: the limits of human performance
results.creator_credit: Steve Skok, Victoria. Dept. of Education and Early Childhood Development and Jeff Spencer
results.brief_description: One of a series of programmes produced in conjunction with the Youth ANZAAS Science Festival. While looking at the differences in human performances at Olympic Games, the question is raised as to how one person can do so much better than another and why performance times have improved so much

results.title: Beating the bracken
results.creator_credit: New South Wales. Dept. of Agriculture
results.brief_description: Recommends methods of removing bracken from the rich dairy country in the New South Wales coastal belt. Explains that broken bracken is the first stage in the removal of the pest. Illustrates the use of specially designed three-bladed rollers on hilly country. On level pastures the simple square log roller with steel flanges, the mower, the rotary hoe, or other mechanical equipment are suggested.
